Plant and animal species—and as a consequence, their pathogens and pests—are translocated across the globe at an ever-increasing rate since the nineteenth century
1 . Most introductions of microorganisms and insects (notably plant pathogens and/or their arthropod vectors) are accidental, while a few are deliberate for biological control purposes
2 . Introductions of plant pathogens can have a dramatic impact on agricultural production and food security
3, 4 and being able to predict the fate of a newly introduced disease based on surveillance data is pivotal to anticipate control actions
